diagnoses.name: Chronic Myeloid Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A form of leukemia characterized by the increased and unregulated growth of myeloid cells in the bone marrow and the accumulation of these cells in the blood.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that causes the bone marrow to make too many red blood cells, which thickens the blood, slowing its flow.

diagnoses.name: Hypersensitivity Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders characterized by inflammation of the blood vessels, which can cause changes in the skin and other symptoms like fever, fatigue, and weight loss.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory lung disease that causes obstructed airflow from the lungs, resulting in breathing difficulty, cough, mucus (sputum) production, and wheezing.

diagnoses.name: Human Papillomavirus (HPV) Infection
diagnoses.description: A viral infection that can cause warts in various parts of the body, depending on the strain.

diagnoses.name: Iron-deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A common type of anemia—a condition in which blood lacks adequate healthy red blood cells—due to insufficient iron, affecting oxygen transport and causing symptoms like fatigue and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, but mostly the lungs and lymph glands. It's characterized by the growth of tiny collections of inflammatory cells in different parts of the body.

diagnoses.name: Essential Thrombocythemia
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which your body produces too many platelets, leading to clotting problems and, in some cases, bleeding.

diagnoses.name: Secondary Polycythemia
diagnoses.description: Occurs when excess red blood cells are produced as a response to an underlying condition, such as chronic hypoxia or tumors producing erythropoietin.

diagnoses.name: Zinc Deficiency
diagnoses.description: A nutritional condition that affects cellular metabolism and the immune system, leading to symptoms like hair loss, diarrhea, and delay in wound healing. It can also cause dysgeusia.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the blood vessels which can cause constriction and reduced blood flow, potentially leading to symptoms like aneurysms, pallor, and hypoglycemia due to impaired organ function.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A disorder of metabolism where glucose levels are poorly managed, leading to hypoglycemia especially in cases where treatment is mismanaged. Lymphadenitis can occur as a secondary infection due to immune system compromise.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Often caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, presenting symptoms such as pallor, lymphadenitis, and splenomegaly. Though less common, it can influence blood sugar levels and cause transient hypoglycemia.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body including blood vessels (contributing to aneurysms and vasculitis), and potentially leading to lymphadenitis and pallor due to systemic inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Marfan Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder affecting connective tissue, often associated with aneurysms, particularly in the aorta. It doesn’t directly cause hypoglycemia, lymphadenitis, or pallor but may have secondary effects that correlate.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: Cancer of the lymphatic system, directly causing lymphadenitis. It can indirectly lead to aneurysm formation through vessel obstruction or weakening, and may also cause pallor due to anemia and hypoglycemia from metabolic disruption.

diagnoses.name: Addison's Disease
diagnoses.description: An endocrine disorder where the adrenal glands produce insufficient hormones, leading to hypoglycemia, and potentially causing pallor. Lymphadenitis might occur in this condition due to overall reduced immunity.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can affect multiple organs, including the lymph nodes (lymphadenitis) and potentially the vascular system, which might indirectly contribute to aneurysms. Pallor and hypoglycemia can result from organ system dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: Polyarteritis Nodosa
diagnoses.description: A serious blood vessel disease where small and medium-sized arteries become swollen and damaged, potentially leading to aneurysms, and can cause symptoms like pallor. Lymphadenitis isn’t directly associated but can be a secondary complication.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of lymphoma which can cause enlarged lymph nodes (lymphadenitis), and can indirectly lead to symptoms such as pallor and hypoglycemia through various metabolic and systemic effects.

diagnoses: Skin and Subcutaneous Tissue Bacterial Infections

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Primary Biliary Cholangitis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that slowly destroys the bile ducts in your liver, often indicated by abnormal liver enzymes.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Hepatitis
diagnoses.description: Long-lasting inflammation of the liver, leading to abnormal liver enzymes.

diagnoses.name: Immunodeficiency Disorders
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders where the immune system's ability to fight infections is impaired, leading to increased susceptibility to infections including otitis media.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus/Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome significantly weakens the immune system, leading to increased susceptibility to various infections and conditions, including otitis media.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Hepatitis
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the body's immune system attacks liver cells, potentially leading to abnormal liver enzymes.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A metabolic disorder that can lead to various complications including dyshidrotic eczema due to skin dehydration and increased susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: Lichen Planus
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory condition that can affect the skin and mucous membranes, sometimes presenting with leukoplakia-like lesions.

diagnoses.name: Non-alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease (NAFLD)
diagnoses.description: A condition where fat builds up in the liver leading to abnormal liver enzymes without heavy alcohol use.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren’s Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands that provide lubrication to the eyes and mouth, can lead to leukoplakia due to dry mouth.

diagnoses.name: Oral Thrush
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by the Candida fungus, leading to creamy white lesions on the tongue or inner cheeks (can resemble leukoplakia) and potentially increasing susceptibility to further infections.

diagnoses: Thyroid disorders (e.g., Graves' disease, Hashimoto's thyroiditis)

diagnoses.name: Upper Respiratory Infection
diagnoses.description: An infection of the upper respiratory tract, which can cause symptoms including sore throat, coryza (common cold symptoms), and oral discomfort due to postnasal drip.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Sinusitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the sinuses that lasts for more than 12 weeks. Symptoms may include nasal congestion, facial pain, and oral pain from sinus pressure.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A digestive disorder where stomach acid frequently flows back into the tube connecting your mouth and stomach (esophagus). This can lead to symptoms such as throat irritation, oral pain, and possibly coryza-like symptoms due to postnasal drip.

diagnoses.name: Oral Thrush
diagnoses.description: A fungal infection in the mouth, which can cause oral pain. It is more common in people with weakened immune systems, and though not directly linked to infertility, underlying health issues could affect fertility.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder causing enlarged ovaries with small cysts on the outer edges. Symptoms include infertility. While PCOS itself does not cause oral pain, laryngitis, or coryza, associated hormonal imbalances may have wide-ranging effects on health.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth that can lead to oral pain. It has been associated with complications that could indirectly affect fertility.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders
diagnoses.description: Both hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism can lead to symptoms such as infertility. Thyroid issues can also impact general health, potentially leading to feeling unwell, which might be misinterpreted as symptoms like coryza.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin Deficiencies
diagnoses.description: Deficiencies in certain vitamins, such as B12 or vitamin D, can cause a range of symptoms including oral pain, weakened immune responses leading to frequent infections like laryngitis, and potentially impact fertility.

diagnoses.name: Sexually Transmitted Infections (STIs)
diagnoses.description: Some STIs can cause infertility if left untreated. While they may not directly cause oral pain or coryza, they can impact overall health including throat infections from oral sex.

diagnoses.name: Oral and Pharyngeal Cancer
diagnoses.description: Though less common, cancers of the mouth and throat can lead to symptoms such as oral pain and difficulty swallowing. Some treatments or the cancer itself could potentially affect fertility.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis)
Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis)
Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD, includes Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis)
Vasovagal syncope (related to syncope and possibly triggered by abdominal cramps or stress)
Urinary tract infection (UTI, can sometimes lead to incontinence)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's disease and Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by visual disturbances and other aura symptoms followed by a severe headache, often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to sound (phonophobia).

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear causing vertigo, hearing loss, tinnitus, and the feeling of pressure deep inside the ear.

diagnoses.name: Vestibular Neuronitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the vestibular nerve causing severe vertigo, but typically without hearing loss.

diagnoses.name: Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV)
diagnoses.description: A disorder stemming from a problem in the inner ear, characterized by repeated episodes of positional vertigo.

diagnoses.name: Viral Labyrinthitis
diagnoses.description: An inner ear infection that can affect hearing and balance, leading to vertigo, hearing loss, and difficulty focusing.

diagnoses.name: Brain Stem or Cerebellar Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurring in the brain stem or cerebellum, affecting balance, coordination, and other basic functions of the body.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system) that can cause weakness, coordination and balance difficulties, and other neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition resulting from poor blood flow in the back of the brain, causing dizziness, vertigo, and other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Migrainous Vertigo
diagnoses.description: Vertigo that is associated with a migraine, either as part of the aura or as a separate symptom.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma
diagnoses.description: A benign tumor on the nerve that connects the ear to the brain, causing hearing loss, vertigo, and imbalance.

diagnoses.details: Complex migraine can manifest with symptoms like visual disturbances (scintillation), language problems (aphasia), headache, and sometimes vomiting.
Symptoms include sudden confusion, trouble speaking, or understanding speech (aphasia), severe headache, and other symptoms depending on the area of the brain affected.
Often called a mini-stroke, it can present with transient symptoms similar to a stroke, such as aphasia, headache, or even scintillations.
Depending on the tumor's location, it can press on parts of the brain responsible for vision (causing scintillations), language (aphasia), and cause headaches or vomiting.
Inflammation of the brain's protective membranes can lead to severe headache, nausea, vomiting, and in severe cases, confusion or problems with language.
Brain inflammation often caused by an infection can lead to headache, problems with speech (aphasia), seizures, and gastrointestinal symptoms like vomiting.
Bleeding within the skull can lead to rising intracranial pressure, causing severe headache, vomiting, aphasia, and visual disturbances.
Some types of seizures can present with transient aphasia, visual disturbances (including scintillation), followed by a postictal state that may include headache and vomiting.
An abscess can cause increased intracranial pressure leading to headache, nausea, vomiting, and depending on its location, visual disturbances or aphasia.

Exposure to carbon monoxide can lead to a wide range of neurological symptoms depending on the exposure level, including headache, visual disturbances, vomiting, and confusion which might mimic aphasia in severe cases.

diagnoses: Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia (associated with autoimmune disorders)
Vasculitis (e.g., Granulomatosis with polyangiitis, Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis)
Hepatitis B or C associated cryoglobulinemia
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
